content: Act as a helpful AI assistant

In Julia, Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is a function that fulfills your requirements:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump::Int=3)
    return dt + Hour(bump)
end

function timezone_bumper(dt::Date, bump::Int=3)
    error("The function timezone_bumper does not accept Date types. Please provide a DateTime object.")
end
```

This function uses the Dates library, which is part of the standard library in Julia. The function `timezone_bumper` accepts any DateTime object and an integer (representing the number of hours to increment the DateTime object) as arguments. If no second argument is provided, the function will default to incrementing the DateTime object by 3 hours.

The function also contains a method that throws an error if a Date object is provided as the first argument. This is because Date objects do not have a time component, and so it doesn't make sense to increment them by a certain number of hours.
